awd_titl_txt: Downgradient Energy Transport and the Atmospheric Circulation
awd_abstract_narration:
The earth’s atmosphere operates as a heat engine, transporting energy from regions of surplus to regions of deficit. The heat transport varies remarkably smoothly with latitude despite the atmosphere having very different circulation patterns across the globe. Emerging research suggests that this heat transport appears to be well-described as a diffusive process that depends on the equator-to-pole energy contrast. If so, such a simple concept may offer a fundamental explanation for many aspects of the observed climatology and climate change (past and future). This research addresses: (i) why this conceptual model of energy transport works so well despite the highly complex atmospheric motion and (ii) the model’s ability to explain the hydrology and global distribution of temperature and atmospheric constituents of past climate states. The description of heat transport as a diffusive process is so fundamental in science that this research has the potential to significantly improve the public understanding of climate science. In addition to mentoring a young research scientist, the researchers will train a graduate student and heavily involve undergraduates in research activities.

Specifically, the researchers seek to understand how the atmospheric circulation adjusts to maintain a nearly linear downgradient energy transport as the climate state changes. Using observations, they will determine how the near-linear relationship between the meridional enthalpy gradient and the atmospheric heat transport emerges as a function of space and time. Furthermore, they will perform numerical experiments that vary the dynamical transport mechanisms (e.g., changing the Earth’s rotation rate and orography) to probe the limits of the near-linear relationship. Finally, the researchers will analyze existing paleoclimate simulations, as well as carefully targeted new simulations, to evaluate how well this simple heat transport model characterizes past climates.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF project was founded on a simple idea about what controls heat transport in the Earth’s atmosphere. The atmosphere can be regarded as a form of thermodynamic heat engine wherein heat is transported from latitudes where there is a surplus (in the tropics) to latitudes where there is a deficit (the middle and high latitudes). The key concept is to recognize the latent-heat energy associated with water vapor. At warmer temperatures Earth’s atmosphere carries exponentially more water vapor than at cooler temperatures, and this forms an important part of the energy content of an atmospheric column. The sum of the sensible heat (the temperature component) and the latent heat (the moisture component) can be termed the moist static energy, or moist enthalpy.

This project developed recent work showing that much of the meridional pattern of climate change, such as polar amplification, can be understood by assuming that the atmosphere transports moist static energy downgradient; that is, from regions where energy is high to regions where energy is low. Moreover, because a component of that energy is in the form of atmospheric moisture, the principle of downgradient transport also explains major changes in the Earth’s hydrologic cycle.

Applied to past climates, we demonstrated how downgradient transport can be used to understand past variations of temperature, hydrology, and water isotopes from ice-core records drilled in polar ice sheets. We showed how the spatial patterns of temperature and hydrologic change that are orchestrated by downgradient transport offer a test of whether climate variability of the Holocene was externally forced or due to internal processes. Our research also found that poleward energy transport remains remarkably similar even under the very different boundary conditions of the last glacial maximum, twenty-thousand years ago.

We used idealized numerical experiments to evaluate mechanisms of atmospheric heat transport. One result was that total atmospheric heat transport remained the same even when huge, hemispheric-scale mountain ranges were introduced into the lower boundary conditions of numerical atmospheric models. Thus, despite powerful new mixing mechanisms being introduced into the atmosphere (known as stationary waves), the overall heat transport is very nearly invariant. The implies a powerful compensatory tendency at work, whereby other mechanisms of heat transport adjust so that the total is unchanged.  The tendency for a diffusive downgradient transport is consistent with this compensation, although the detailed mechanisms remain to be understood. An undergraduate, mentored by two graduate students, led a piece of the project that showed that the details of the spatial pattern of the heat-transport efficiency do not matter – the results are robust provided there is some tendency for downgradient transport.

Applied to modern and future climate, we used the principle of downgradient transport to explain how climate feedbacks contribute to the projected spatial pattern of hydrologic change (and uncertainty in future projections); we evaluated trends in observed atmospheric heat transport; and seasonal changes in projected heat transport. In terms of intellectual merits, we believe the project has served to cement the principle of downgradient transport as a valuable framework, both conceptual and quantitative, for understanding past, present, and future patterns of temperature and hydrologic change.

The project was particularly productive in terms of publications, providing support for 24 peer-reviewed publications, and 12 conference or workshop presentations. In terms of education, the project provided significant funding for one research scientist and two PhD students. As per the proposal’s broader impacts, the project supported three undergraduate researchers on work that led to first-author publications for them, and subsequent placement in graduate schools (Oxford, Stanford, San José).
